title: Job Chapter 5 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 5 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 5 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 5.

questions.question: According to Job 5:1, to whom does the speaker suggest you should turn for answers?
questions.explanation: Job 5:1 specifically asks to which of the saints one will turn for answers.

questions.question: What does wrath do to a foolish man according to Job 5:2?
questions.explanation: Job 5:2 states that wrath killeth the foolish man.

questions.question: True or False: Job 5:7 says that trouble comes from the dust.
questions.explanation: Job 5:6 states affliction does not come from dust, and Job 5:7 says man is born unto trouble like sparks fly upward, not from dust.

questions.question: Who does the speaker say he would seek and commit his cause to in Job 5:8?
questions.explanation: Job 5:8 clearly says, 'I would seek unto God, and unto God would I commit my cause.'

questions.question: What does God give upon the earth as mentioned in Job 5:10?
questions.explanation: Job 5:10 says God giveth rain upon the earth and sendeth waters upon the fields.

questions.question: According to Job 5:11, who does God set up on high?
questions.explanation: Job 5:11 states God sets up on high those that be low.

questions.question: True or False: Job 5:12 says that God helps the crafty to perform their enterprises.
questions.explanation: Job 5:12 says God disappointeth the devices of the crafty, so their hands cannot perform their enterprise.

questions.question: What do the wise get caught in according to Job 5:13?
questions.explanation: Job 5:13 says God taketh the wise in their own craftiness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Job 5:14: 'They meet with ______ in the daytime, and grope in the noonday as in the night.'
questions.explanation: Job 5:14 states they meet with darkness in the daytime.

questions.question: According to Job 5:15, whom does God save from the sword and the hand of the mighty?
questions.explanation: Job 5:15 says God saveth the poor from the sword, from their mouth, and from the hand of the mighty.

questions.question: True or False: Job 5:17 encourages despising the chastening of the Almighty.
questions.explanation: Job 5:17 says happy is the man whom God correcteth, so do not despise the chastening of the Almighty.

questions.question: In Job 5:18, what does God do after He makes sore?
questions.explanation: Job 5:18 says He maketh sore, and bindeth up; He woundeth, and His hands make whole.

questions.question: How many troubles will God deliver you from according to Job 5:19?
questions.explanation: Job 5:19 states God shall deliver thee in six troubles; yea, in seven there shall no evil touch thee.

questions.question: According to Job 5:21, what shall you not be afraid of?
questions.explanation: Job 5:21 says thou shalt be hid from the scourge of the tongue and shalt not be afraid of destruction when it cometh.

questions.question: According to Job 5:26, how is the coming to your grave described?
options: Like a shock of corn in its season
questions.correctAnswer: Like a shock of corn in its season
questions.explanation: Job 5:26 says thou shalt come to thy grave in a full age, like as a shock of corn cometh in in his season.

medium.title: Job Chapter 5 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 5 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Job 5, what biblical truth would you share about God's correction?
options: God's correction is a sign of His love and brings eventual healing
God punishes without purpose or hope of restoration
Trials are random and unrelated to God's will
We should despise God's chastening as unfair
questions.correctAnswer: God's correction is a sign of His love and brings eventual healing
questions.explanation: Verses 17-18 explain that God corrects and chastens those He loves, making sore but also binding up and healing, showing His discipline is for our good.

questions.question: How does Job 5 teach us about trusting God during times of trouble?
options: We should seek God and commit our cause to Him because He performs great and marvelous works
We must rely only on human wisdom and avoid God
Troubles come without reason and God cannot help
God is indifferent to our suffering
questions.correctAnswer: We should seek God and commit our cause to Him because He performs great and marvelous works
questions.explanation: Verse 8 encourages seeking God and committing our cause to Him, and verses 9-10 highlight God's great and unsearchable works, showing His power and care.

questions.question: What does Job 5 say about the fate of the foolish and envious?
options: Wrath kills the foolish and envy slays the silly
They are always protected and blessed
Their folly leads to riches and honor
questions.correctAnswer: Wrath kills the foolish and envy slays the silly
questions.explanation: Verse 2 clearly states that wrath kills the foolish and envy slays the silly, teaching caution against these sins.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by schemes of the crafty. According to Job 5, what hope is offered?
options: God frustrates the plans of the crafty so their hands cannot perform their schemes
The crafty always succeed without consequence
We should join the crafty to survive
questions.correctAnswer: God frustrates the plans of the crafty so their hands cannot perform their schemes
questions.explanation: Verses 12-13 describe how God disappoints the devices of the crafty and brings down the counsel of the froward, offering hope to the oppressed.

questions.question: How does Job 5 describe God's care for the poor and afflicted?
options: God saves the poor from the sword and gives them hope
The poor are forgotten and left to suffer
We must depend on ourselves only
God punishes the poor without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: God saves the poor from the sword and gives them hope
questions.explanation: Verses 15-16 reveal that God saves the poor from danger and gives them hope, silencing iniquity's accusations.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 5, man is born to live a trouble-free life.
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states that man is born unto trouble, like sparks flying upward, indicating trials are part of life.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'He shall deliver thee in six troubles: yea, in _____ there shall no evil touch thee.'
questions.explanation: Verse 19 promises deliverance in six troubles and safety in seven, symbolizing complete protection.

questions.question: How does Job 5 illustrate the blessing of family and legacy?
options: Your seed will be great and your offspring like the grass of the earth
Family is unimportant in God's plan
Children bring only trouble and worry
questions.correctAnswer: Your seed will be great and your offspring like the grass of the earth
questions.explanation: Verse 25 affirms that a godly life leads to a great multitude of descendants, emphasizing the blessing of family.

questions.question: A believer is fearful of destruction and famine. What assurance does Job 5 give?
options: You shall laugh at destruction and famine and not fear the beasts of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: You shall laugh at destruction and famine and not fear the beasts of the earth
questions.explanation: Verses 22-23 provide assurance of peace and safety even amidst dangers, promising confidence in God's protection.

questions.question: According to Job 5, what is the outcome for those who trust God regarding their dwelling and conduct?
options: Their tabernacle shall be in peace and they shall not sin
They will live in constant fear and sin often
They must rely on their own strength alone
questions.correctAnswer: Their tabernacle shall be in peace and they shall not sin
questions.explanation: Verse 24 promises peace in one's dwelling and righteous living for those who trust God.

questions.question: How does Job 5 describe God's control over nature and provision?
options: God gives rain on the earth and sends waters on the fields
questions.correctAnswer: God gives rain on the earth and sends waters on the fields
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states God’s providential care in sustaining the earth and crops through rain and water.

questions.question: True or False: Job 5 teaches that God is unaware of human suffering and does not intervene.
questions.explanation: Throughout Job 5, God is shown as active in correcting, protecting, and delivering His people (verses 17-21).

questions.question: What does Job 5 suggest about the consequences of wicked plans?
options: The crafty are caught in their own craftiness and their plans fail
Evil schemes remain hidden and prosper
One should imitate the crafty to succeed
questions.correctAnswer: The crafty are caught in their own craftiness and their plans fail
questions.explanation: Verse 13 says God catches the wise in their own craftiness and their counsel is overthrown.

questions.question: How should a believer respond to God's chastening according to Job 5?
options: Do not despise it; it is for our good
Ignore it and continue as before
questions.correctAnswer: Do not despise it; it is for our good
questions.explanation: Verse 17 advises happiness for those God corrects and warns not to despise His chastening because it is beneficial.

questions.question: What encouragement does Job 5 give about living a full life and dying in peace?
options: You will come to your grave in full age like a shock of corn in its season
One’s end depends on wealth and power
questions.correctAnswer: You will come to your grave in full age like a shock of corn in its season
questions.explanation: Verse 26 uses the metaphor of ripe grain to symbolize a full, blessed life and peaceful death.

hard.title: Job Chapter 5 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 5.

questions.question: In Job 5:7, what is man compared to in relation to trouble?
questions.explanation: Job 5:7 states 'Yet man is born unto trouble, as the sparks fly upward,' using a simile to illustrate the inevitability of human suffering.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is emphasized in Job 5:9 as performing 'great things and unsearchable'?
questions.explanation: Job 5:9 highlights God's power by describing His deeds as 'great things and unsearchable,' pointing to His omnipotence beyond human comprehension.

questions.question: What does Job 5:10 say God sends upon the earth and fields?
questions.explanation: Job 5:10 mentions God 'giveth rain upon the earth, and sendeth waters upon the fields,' reflecting the ancient Near Eastern understanding of divine provision for agriculture.

questions.question: How does Job 5:12 describe God's action toward the devices of the crafty?
questions.explanation: Job 5:12 states 'He disappointeth the devices of the crafty,' indicating God's intervention against deceitful human plans.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the Hebrew word translated as 'froward' in Job 5:13?
questions.explanation: The term 'froward' in Job 5:13 refers to those who are perverse or stubborn, highlighting the futility of their counsels against God's will.

questions.question: In Job 5:14, what metaphor is used to describe the condition of the wise and froward?
questions.explanation: Job 5:14 uses the paradoxical image of 'They meet with darkness in the daytime, and grope in the noonday as in the night' to illustrate confusion and misguidance.

questions.question: According to Job 5:17, why should one not despise the chastening of the Almighty?
options: Because God corrects the happy man
Because it is a sign of punishment
questions.correctAnswer: Because God corrects the happy man
questions.explanation: Job 5:17 states 'Behold, happy is the man whom God correcteth,' implying that divine correction is a mark of favor and leads to happiness.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Job 5:18 to describe God's actions?
questions.explanation: Job 5:18 employs parallelism: 'For he maketh sore, and bindeth up: he woundeth, and his hands make whole,' balancing contrasting actions to emphasize God's restorative power.

questions.question: Job 5:19 mentions deliverance in 'six troubles' and 'seven.' What does this numerical style reflect in ancient Near Eastern literature?
options: A poetic way to express completeness
questions.correctAnswer: A poetic way to express completeness
questions.explanation: The use of 'six' and 'seven' in Job 5:19 reflects a common ancient Near Eastern literary device symbolizing completeness or perfection in suffering and deliverance.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 5:23, the beasts of the field will be hostile to the person who trusts in God.
questions.explanation: Job 5:23 states 'the beasts of the field shall be at peace with thee,' indicating harmony rather than hostility.

questions.question: In Job 5:25, what is the metaphor used to describe the offspring or seed of the person?
questions.explanation: Job 5:25 compares offspring to 'the grass of the earth,' symbolizing abundance and growth.

questions.question: How does Job 5:26 use agricultural imagery to describe the life span of the person?
options: Like a shock of corn coming in his season
Like a tree planted by water
Like a flower blooming in spring
questions.correctAnswer: Like a shock of corn coming in his season
questions.explanation: Job 5:26 uses the metaphor of a full harvest—a shock of corn harvested in season—to describe a long, complete life.

questions.question: What is the primary theme of Job 5:8-16 regarding the relationship between man and God?
options: Trust in God's justice and provision despite suffering
God's wrath as punishment without hope
The futility of human effort against nature
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God's justice and provision despite suffering
questions.explanation: Verses 8-16 emphasize seeking God who performs marvelous deeds, delivers the poor, and provides hope, underscoring trust amid adversity.

questions.question: Job 5:6 mentions that affliction does not come 'forth of the dust.' How does this statement contrast with the creation narrative in Genesis?
options: It implies suffering originates beyond natural causes, unlike man formed from dust
It affirms that affliction is part of creation from dust
It denies God's role in creation
It suggests that humans are immune to suffering
questions.correctAnswer: It implies suffering originates beyond natural causes, unlike man formed from dust
questions.explanation: In Genesis 2:7, man is formed from dust, but Job 5:6 states affliction does not arise from dust, implying suffering has a supernatural or divine dimension beyond natural origins.

questions.question: According to Job 5:1, to whom does the speaker suggest Job should turn for answers?
questions.explanation: Job 5:1 says, 'Call now, if there be any that will answer thee; and to which of the saints wilt thou turn?' indicating the expectation to seek wise counsel from the godly.

theological.title: Job Chapter 5 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 5 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Job 5:7, what is the nature of man's existence in relation to trouble?
options: Man is born unto trouble like sparks fly upward
Man is born without any trouble
Man can avoid trouble by wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Man is born unto trouble like sparks fly upward
questions.explanation: Job 5:7 states 'Yet man is born unto trouble, as the sparks fly upward,' indicating that human life inherently involves trouble. This is consistent with passages like Genesis 3:17-19 on the curse of sin, Romans 8:20-22 on creation's bondage to frustration, Ecclesiastes 1:13 on vanity, John 16:33 on tribulation, and 1 Peter 4:12 on suffering as part of the Christian experience.

questions.question: In Job 5:8, to whom does the speaker advise to commit their cause?
questions.explanation: Job 5:8 says, 'I would seek unto God, and unto God would I commit my cause,' emphasizing reliance on God for justice and deliverance. This aligns with Psalm 37:5 on committing one’s way to the Lord, Proverbs 3:5-6 on trusting God, Isaiah 41:10 on God’s help, Romans 12:19 on leaving vengeance to God, and Hebrews 4:16 on approaching God's throne for mercy.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is highlighted in Job 5:9 as He performs "great things and unsearchable; marvellous things without number"?
questions.explanation: Job 5:9 describes God as performing 'great things and unsearchable; marvellous things without number,' highlighting His omnipotence and inscrutable wisdom. This corresponds with Isaiah 40:28 on God's everlasting power, Romans 11:33 on unsearchable judgments, Psalm 147:5 on God's understanding, Jeremiah 32:17 on God's mighty acts, and Colossians 1:16 on God's creative power.

questions.question: According to Job 5:11, what does God do for those who mourn?
questions.explanation: Job 5:11 says God 'sets up on high those that be low; that those which mourn may be exalted to safety,' showing God's care to uplift the humble and comfort the afflicted. This is consistent with Psalm 147:3 on healing the brokenhearted, Isaiah 61:1-3 on comforting mourners, Matthew 5:4 on blessedness of the mourners, Revelation 21:4 on wiping away tears, and 2 Corinthians 1:3-4 on God comforting us.

questions.question: What does Job 5:12 say about God's action towards the crafty?
options: He disappoints their devices so they cannot succeed
questions.correctAnswer: He disappoints their devices so they cannot succeed
questions.explanation: Job 5:12 states, 'He disappointeth the devices of the crafty, so that their hands cannot perform their enterprise,' showing God's justice in thwarting evil plans. This parallels Proverbs 1:10-19 warning against evil counsel, Psalm 37:12-15 on the downfall of the wicked, Isaiah 59:1-2 on God opposing the wicked, Romans 1:18 on God's wrath against unrighteousness, and James 4:6 on God opposing the proud.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Job 5:16 says, "So the poor hath hope, and __________ stoppeth her mouth."
questions.explanation: Job 5:16 declares, 'So the poor hath hope, and iniquity stoppeth her mouth,' indicating that the poor find hope and that injustice is silenced. This resonates with Psalm 9:18 on the poor not being forgotten, Isaiah 1:17 on defending the poor, Luke 4:18 on proclaiming freedom to the oppressed, and James 5:4 on the cry of the oppressed.

questions.question: What does Job 5:17 say about the man whom God corrects?
questions.explanation: Job 5:17 states, 'Behold, happy is the man whom God correcteth,' affirming the blessedness of divine discipline. This aligns with Hebrews 12:5-11 on God’s discipline producing holiness, Proverbs 3:11-12 on the Lord's correction, Psalm 94:12 on blessedness of correction, Revelation 3:19 on loving discipline, and James 1:2-4 on trials producing endurance.

questions.question: According to Job 5:18, what paradoxical actions does God perform?
options: He maketh sore, and bindeth up; he woundeth, and his hands make whole
questions.correctAnswer: He maketh sore, and bindeth up; he woundeth, and his hands make whole
questions.explanation: Job 5:18 describes God's paradoxical work: 'He maketh sore, and bindeth up; he woundeth, and his hands make whole,' showing His sovereign control over suffering and healing. This corresponds with Deuteronomy 32:39 on God's power over life and death, Psalm 147:3 on healing the brokenhearted, Isaiah 53:5 on wounds bringing healing, Romans 8:28 on God's purposes in suffering, and James 5:14-15 on healing through prayer.

questions.question: What assurance does Job 5:19 give regarding God's deliverance?
options: He shall deliver thee in six troubles; yea, in seven there shall no evil touch thee
He shall deliver only some troubles
He does not deliver from trouble
He delivers only in the afterlife
questions.correctAnswer: He shall deliver thee in six troubles; yea, in seven there shall no evil touch thee
questions.explanation: Job 5:19 promises deliverance 'in six troubles; yea, in seven there shall no evil touch thee,' symbolizing complete divine protection. This theme of God's protection appears in Psalm 34:19 on many troubles with deliverance, Isaiah 43:2 on protection through hardships, John 10:28 on no one snatching from the Father's hand, Romans 8:38-39 on inseparability from God's love, and 2 Corinthians 1:10 on deliverance from deadly peril.

questions.question: From Job 5:20, in what situations does God redeem the believer?
options: In famine from death, and in war from the power of the sword
questions.correctAnswer: In famine from death, and in war from the power of the sword
questions.explanation: Job 5:20 states, 'In famine he shall redeem thee from death: and in war from the power of the sword,' showing God's salvation amid extreme dangers. This echoes Exodus 12:13 on protection in judgment, Psalm 91:3-7 on deliverance from deadly pestilence, Isaiah 54:17 on no weapon prospering, Matthew 6:25-34 on God's provision, and Revelation 12:11 on overcoming by the blood of the Lamb.

questions.question: According to Job 5:23, what relationship will the believer have with the natural world?
options: The beasts of the field shall be at peace with thee
The beasts shall attack the believer
The believer will dominate the beasts violently
There will be no interaction with animals
questions.correctAnswer: The beasts of the field shall be at peace with thee
questions.explanation: Job 5:23 says, 'the beasts of the field shall be at peace with thee,' indicating harmony between the believer and creation. This reflects Genesis 1:28 on dominion with stewardship, Isaiah 11:6-9 on peace among animals in the messianic age, Romans 8:19-22 on creation’s redemption, Revelation 21:1 on new creation, and Psalm 72:7 on peace in the land.

questions.question: What promise about the believer’s descendants is found in Job 5:25?
options: Thy seed shall be great, and thine offspring as the grass of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Thy seed shall be great, and thine offspring as the grass of the earth
questions.explanation: Job 5:25 promises abundance of descendants: 'Thy seed shall be great, and thine offspring as the grass of the earth,' reflecting God’s covenant blessings. This corresponds with Genesis 12:2 on multiplying descendants, Psalm 127:3-5 on children as heritage, Isaiah 44:3 on descendants blessed, Matthew 22:30 on resurrection and continuity, and Hebrews 11:12 on faith in God's promise to Abraham.

questions.question: Job 5:26 compares coming to one's grave to what natural image?
options: Like a shock of corn cometh in in his season
questions.correctAnswer: Like a shock of corn cometh in in his season
questions.explanation: Job 5:26 says, 'Thou shalt come to thy grave in a full age, like as a shock of corn cometh in in his season,' symbolizing a full life completed in God’s timing. This imagery aligns with Psalm 90:10 on lifespan, Ecclesiastes 3:1-2 on seasons for everything, John 12:24 on dying to bear fruit, 1 Corinthians 15:36-38 on resurrection and harvest, and James 4:14 on life’s brevity.

questions.question: What reason does Job 5:17 give for not despising the chastening of the Almighty?
options: Because God corrects the happy man
questions.correctAnswer: Because God corrects the happy man
questions.explanation: Job 5:17 says, 'Behold, happy is the man whom God correcteth: therefore despise not thou the chastening of the Almighty,' encouraging acceptance of divine discipline. This teaching is confirmed in Proverbs 3:11-12 on the Lord’s correction, Hebrews 12:6 on God’s discipline as sonship, Revelation 3:19 on loving rebuke, and Psalm 119:67 on learning through affliction.

questions.question: What does Job 5:14 describe about the fate of the froward and crafty?
options: They meet with darkness in the daytime, and grope in the noonday as in the night
They walk in light and truth
questions.correctAnswer: They meet with darkness in the daytime, and grope in the noonday as in the night
questions.explanation: Job 5:14 states, 'They meet with darkness in the daytime, and grope in the noonday as in the night,' illustrating confusion and judgment on the wicked. This parallels Isaiah 59:9 on darkness instead of light, John 3:19 on men loving darkness, 2 Corinthians 4:4 on the god of this world blinding minds, Psalm 34:18 on God close to brokenhearted, and Proverbs 4:19 on the way of the wicked being like darkness.
